snippet.title: Salad Mug - DYNAMO DREAM, Episode 1
snippet.description:
Feels so good to finally post this! Unending thanks to all the friends who worked to help make this happen, and all of the folks over on the patreon! 

A lot changed over the course of making this episode (you can probably feel it), and while I'm really excited about this episode, I'm even more excited to keep everything moving for the next bit; the big goal is to be able to finish these things a bit faster than every 3 years :P 

Thanks so much for watching- I hope you enjoy it. 

If you DID enjoy it and want to chip in a bit financially for future episodes, I've documented a ton of the process (and shared a bunch of assets) over on my Patreon. Mostly VFX/blender tutorials and such, but also more general breakdowns, too, and I'd of course love to see you there. 
http://www.patreon.com/IanHubert

Also, HUGE thanks to Impossible Acoustic for being down to take on this project! The degree to which the audio sculpts the end experience here is absolutely wild. 
https://www.impossibleacoustic.com

Composited in After Effects, 
All 3d work in Blender (blender.org)

Huge thanks again, to everyone :D

snippet.title: HyperBole! The Hyperball Hates You
snippet.description:
www.patreon.com/IanHubert
Finally finished this up! Sorry to anyone who thought it was going to be longer; that'd be a blast some day, but this got it out of my system for now :) 

Solid mix of hand animated stuff, physics sims, and data from a Rokoko mocap suit (learned a ton about IK rigging, too, to mix it all up)!

Music by Wilbert Roget II
Thanks to the Photoscanned Models, 
Sean Farbolin, Kaitlin Romig, Johnny Valencia, Nate Taylor, Ian Hubert

Made in blender, with some After Effects postwork

Just a quick intro to IK rigging! It's probably the most useful thing I learned last year (after putting it off for, like, literally a decade and a half).

snippet.title: VFX Breakdown - Dynamo Dream Teaser
snippet.description:
First Episode Here: https://youtu.be/LsGZ_2RuJ2A

Hoh man- the little compressed instagram version of this breakdown has been reposted so many times I figured it'd be good to release a version with a couple more pixels!

I've been really excited about this type of workflow in terms of what it means for making crazy films in a garage, and I've been experimenting a bunch with it in the months since (tons of viewport compositing in Blender. All the CG stuff in this video is blender's realtime eevee engine, which has just been a blast). I've been posting lots of breakdowns/tuts/experiments on the patreon (thank you to everyone over there!):
https://www.patreon.com/IanHubert
Although I'm still working on full-on- tutorials I'll be posting here for everyone pretty quick. Almost done! Bit off more than I could chew for a minute here :P

The original Dynamo Dream teaser: 
https://youtu.be/qG31WSioSxk

snippet.title: What's new in Megascans? Ep. 11 | Trees Special
snippet.description:
Announcing the latest Megascans Trees: Common Hazel pack. 🌳

Get an in-depth view of the latest Hazel pack and the most recent releases including Black Alder, Hornbeam and Beech packs.

The Common Hazel pack is available to download now on the Unreal Engine Marketplace: https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/product/megascans-trees-common-hazel-early-access

snippet.title: What's new in Megascans? Ep. 10
snippet.description:
Industrial assets make up a diverse and large portion of the Megascans library which can be used to shape any number of environments such as a storage facility, a construction site, a textile factory, or even a warehouse in ruins.

With the plethora of industrial assets available in the Megascans library, there are plenty of avenues you can take to address, reshape, and enhance your scenes further by adding the extra details to help your environment stand out.

Browse our range of industrial assets in the Megascans library: https://quixel.world/a72

snippet.title: 8-Series v10.01 Live Stream
snippet.description:
Register now for a special live-streaming event, Wednesday, May 29th, 2024, at 11:00am CDT (4:00pm GMT), when Director of Product Management and Design Paul Isaacs and Technical Support Expert Laura Sillanpää will go over some of the new features in the 8-Series v10.01 firmware update. snippet.title: A20-Nexus Go and A20-TX Live-Streaming Demo
snippet.description:
Stream Start 08:37
A20-Nexus Go 37:00
Q/A  1:00:00


Join us to learn about the new A20-Nexus Go and A20-TX! 

Are you curious to learn about the newest additions to our Astral family of wireless gear? On August 3rd, at 10:00am CDT (3:00pm GMT), Sound Devices will host a live-streaming event online where Director of Product Design and Management Paul Isaacs and RF Applications Engineer Gary Trenda will demonstrate the new A20-Nexus Go multichannel true-diversity wireless receiver and A20-TX digital wireless transmitter. Following the demonstration, you’ll have the opportunity to ask Paul and Gary questions for them to answer live. 

With 4 receiver channels that can be expanded to 6 and 8 with software expansion licenses and a form factor compact enough for a bag or a half-unit space on a sound cart, the A20-Nexus Go receiver is ready for any application. It has SpectraBand’s 169-1525 MHz global tuning range, the ability to set gain at the receiver and not the transmitter with GainForward, long-range remote control of transmitters via NexLink, integrated RTSA (Real Time Spectrum Analyzer), and more. 

The A20-TX transmitter is compatible with the widest array of input sources, from lavs and dynamic mics, to phantom-powered condenser mics, balanced line-level sources, and even AES digital mics. It accepts AA batteries of any chemistry, and offers a battery life up to 12 hours. The A20-TX transmitter includes the first full, true balanced ultra-low-noise high-headroom mic preamp, and has Astral-family features, like NexLink, SpectraBand, and GainForward.

snippet.title: Meet the A20-TX transmitter and A20-Nexus Go receiver
snippet.description:
Sound Devices introduces two new products: the A20-TX transmitter and A20-Nexus Go receiver!

 

The A20-TX is a digital wireless bodypack transmitter with a multipurpose input, flexible powering scheme, an ultra-low-power e-Paper display, and GainForward Architecture.

 

The A20-Nexus Go true-diversity wireless receiver has four base channels and can be expanded to 6 or 8 with 2-channel software licenses. It features SpectraBand’s 169-1525MHz tuning range, NexLink long-range remote control of transmitters, and is designed for portability.

 

More information on A20-TX, A20-Nexus Go, and all Astral-family products, visit www.sounddevices.com/astral

snippet.title: MixPre II Livestream: Production Sound Basics
snippet.description:
Join us for a very special live stream event featuring our MixPre II Series of mixer-recorders. snippet.title: Cha Che Chi Day Two
snippet.description:
Chabón, chango, chava, chela, checar, chicha, chichón, chido, chimichurri, chulo, churro —the ch* sounds reverberate throughout Latin America. And now, we bring all that rhythmic cacophony to you in typographic resonance—a virtual conference featuring Latin American typographic excellence and insight.

The Cha Che Chi conference was held online on March 3rd and 4th, as a two-day showcase of presentations and panels on what’s happening in Latin American typography today.

DAY TWO SCHEDULE
- Introduction / Ksenya Samarskaya
- #NiUnaMenos: The Collective Power of Women / Sol Matas, Yani Arabena, Cyla Costa, Fernanda Cozzi
- Why do we want new fonts? / Raphaël Verona
- Murals: Take the risk and go big / Ximena Jiménez
- Call to Action, Type in Political and Social contexts / Tulio Cerquize, Laureano Menéndez, Gustavo Greco, Daniel Sabino
- Type Tour: Pichação in São Paulo / Tony de Marco
- Imperfect letters from the south / Guillermo Vizzari
- Design in Translation / Beatriz Lozano

snippet.title: Not Typecast: Two Women and their Typography at Mid-Century
snippet.description:
Briar Levit and Anne Galperin tell the stories of Ellen Raskin and Betti Broadwater Haft, two New York-based contemporaries: one an illustrator turned book designer, turned author and the other, a multidisciplinary designer who was one of the rare women to design a typeface for Photo-lettering Inc. These are just two of the many histories featured in the forthcoming book of essays, “Baseline Shift: Untold Stories of Women in Graphic Design History.”

- - - - 

About the Speakers

BRIAR LEVIT is an Associate Professor of Graphic Design at Portland State University. She studied at San Francisco State University for her undergraduate degree in graphic design and at Central Saint Martins in London for her MA in Communication Design. Levit spent her early career in publishing as Art Director of Bitch: Feminist Response to Pop Culture magazine as well as an independent book designer. Her self-initiated publications are walking books that challenge the existing hiking guide genre. More recently, Levit’s feature-length documentary, Graphic Means: A History of Graphic Design Production (2017) which follows design production from manual to digital methods, established an obsession with design history—particularly aspects not in the canon. She currently co-directs The People’s Graphic Design Archive with Louise Sandhaus and Brockett Horne and has edited a book of essays debuting October 26th, 2021 entitled “Baseline Shift: Previously Untold Stories of Women Throughout Graphic Design History.”

ANNE GALPERIN is an Associate Professor of Art, and Graphic Design program director at the State University of New York at New Paltz. She earned a BSc in Human Development and Social Policy from Northwestern University, and an MFA in 2D Design from Cranbrook Academy of Art. Before entering academia, Galperin edited and wrote for the Macmillan Publishing Company, was a freelance writer and researcher, and designed books in-house at Chronicle Books. Her body of work includes book design for alt-press, museum, and art book clients, including Four Walls Eight Windows/OR Books, the Walker Art Center, and Distributed Art Publishers. Her essay about American Designer Betti Broadwater Haft is included in “Baseline Shift: Untold Stories of Women in Graphic Design History”, edited by Briar Levit and to be released in late October 2021

About the Speakers

BRIAR LEVIT is an Associate Professor of Graphic Design at Portland State University. She studied at San Francisco State University for her undergraduate degree in graphic design and at Central Saint Martins in London for her MA in Communication Design. Levit spent her early career in publishing as Art Director of Bitch: Feminist Response to Pop Culture magazine as well as an independent book designer. Her self-initiated publications are walking books that challenge the existing hiking guide genre. More recently, Levit’s feature-length documentary, Graphic Means: A History of Graphic Design Production (2017) which follows design production from manual to digital methods, established an obsession with design history—particularly aspects not in the canon. She currently co-directs The People’s Graphic Design Archive with Louise Sandhaus and Brockett Horne and has edited a book of essays debuting October 26th, 2021 entitled “Baseline Shift: Previously Untold Stories of Women Throughout Graphic Design History.”

ANNE GALPERIN is an Associate Professor of Art, and Graphic Design program director at the State University of New York at New Paltz. She earned a BSc in Human Development and Social Policy from Northwestern University, and an MFA in 2D Design from Cranbrook Academy of Art. Before entering academia, Galperin edited and wrote for the Macmillan Publishing Company, was a freelance writer and researcher, and designed books in-house at Chronicle Books. Her body of work includes book design for alt-press, museum, and art book clients, including Four Walls Eight Windows/OR Books, the Walker Art Center, and Distributed Art Publishers. Her essay about American Designer Betti Broadwater Haft is included in “Baseline Shift: Untold Stories of Women in Graphic Design History”, edited by Briar Levit and to be released in late October 2021

snippet.title: Meet the Judges III: LGC Judges Day
snippet.description:
Virtual Event
Wednesday, January 19, 2022

Meet the third group of 25TDC Typeface Design judges. Moderated by Ksenya Samarskaya, Committee Co-Chair.

At this event, the judges for the LGC (Latin, Greek, Cyrillic) categories discuss their work, the state of communication design and typography today, and what they’ll be looking for when selecting the best typeface design in the world.

    Kostas Bartsokas
    Martin Majoor
    Daria Petrova
    Ulrike Rausch
    Kara Gordon

Please watch previous sessions (labelled "Global Judges Day" to hear from the judges for CJK (Chinese, Japanese, Korean), Indic, and Arabic scripts. (A total of four sessions for this year's competition.) 

You can also meet the judges the Communication Design competition in "Meet the Judges II".

snippet.title: Towards a Global Definition of Excellence in Type Design - Part 3: Arabic
snippet.description:
Meet some of the 25TDC Typeface Design Jury moderated by Nadine Chahine, Committee Co-Chair.

This is part 3 of a three part series. 

This year marks the expansion of TDC’s Typeface Design Competition with 3 extra categories added for Arabic, Indic, and CJK (Chinese, Japanese, and Korean) scripts. While TDC has long accepted entries in these categories, 2021 marks the first year with multiple dedicated judges for these categories. Each of these categories has 3 judges known for their expertise in that field.

In this video our inaugural judges discuss how one can define excellence in type design in each of these 3 categories, if there is anything there that is unique to that script’s historical printing and typographic history, and to discuss the general state of type design at this point in time.

If you are interested in submitting an original typeface design please visit: 
https://tdc.oneclub.org

snippet.title: “Person Place Thing” with Bobby Martin Jr.
snippet.description:
Virtual Event 
09.20.2021

Bobby C. Martin Jr. is co-founder of Champions Design, a branding and design agency headquartered in New York City.

He sets the relentless standard of design and vision for the agency he founded, with Jennifer Kinon, in 2010. Together they have partnered with a wide range of clients such as Amazon, Apple, Dartmouth College, Girl Scouts, MTV, the National Basketball Association and The Studio Museum in Harlem.

Martin recently illustrated his first children’s book “Have I Ever Told You Black Lives Matter” (Tilbury House). In 2020, he was featured in the renowned design publication, Eye Magazine’s iconic 100th issue.

He has lectured about brand identity around the world, sat on numerous awards juries, and has been a special guest on Design Matters, Design Observer and NPR’s Studio 360. Martin served as a board member of AIGA/NY from 2006-08, and the board of the Type Directors Club from 2014-2021. In 2019, Champions Design was named one of the 30 Most Important Companies in Design by Fast Company. Bobby Martin has won numerous international awards from the AIGA, Art Directors Club, Communication Arts, D&AD, and the TDC, among others. He is a graduate of Virginia Commonwealth University, and earned an MFA from the School of Visual Arts where he currently serves on the faculty.

Randy Cohen’s first professional work was writing humor pieces, essays, and stories for newspapers and magazines (The New Yorker, Harpers, the Atlantic, Young Love Comics). His first television work was writing for “Late Night With David Letterman” for which he won three Emmy awards. His fourth Emmy was for his work on Michael Moore’s “TV Nation.” He received a fifth Emmy as a result of a clerical error, and he kept it. For twelve years he wrote “The Ethicist,” a weekly column for the New York Times Magazine. In 2010, his first play, “The Punishing Blow,” ran at New York’s Clurman Theater. His most recent book, “Be Good: how to navigate the ethics of everything,” was published by Chronicle. He is currently the creator and host of Person Place Thing, a public radio program.

snippet.title: Playing with Words, Playing with Type — Eric Widjaja
snippet.description:
Virtual Event
May 20, 2021

ERIC WIDJAJA founded Jakarta-based design studio Thinking*Room in 2005 after finding his love for graphic design in music and graduated from the Academy of Art University, San Francisco. His work in telling a story with a clear voice and lasting characters through design, from working for brands to self-initiated projects, is established across the country and internationally.

RITTER WILLY PUTRA is an Art Director at Thinking*Room since 2017 with broad expertise from designing for brand identity, installations to publications. He embraces story in design from the largest to the minuscule detail. His notable projects go as diverse as developing sculpture design for the Gelora Bung Karno Stadium in Jakarta to designing for Indonesian unicorn e-commerce, Bukalapak.

snippet.title: This is the next art app that's actually worth downloading: Cara.
snippet.description:
Sorry Jingna & Cara team... but I hope the app keeps blowing up and racks up server costs into the millions xD I think there is something really profound that this app is not only doing extremely well so quickly, but it was birthed from someone who has been involved in the community at our level. Someone who has contributed to the progress of Artistic and Creative legislation. I love that so much of the art community at every corner is involved in this and giving it a chance. I wanted to contribute my part to help keep the momentum going. We shape not only the physical world we live in, but the online landscape as well. I encourage everyone to make a stand today and demand the future you want without anyone else's permission.

localized.title: This is the next art app that's actually worth downloading: Cara.
localized.description:
Sorry Jingna & Cara team... but I hope the app keeps blowing up and racks up server costs into the millions xD I think there is something really profound that this app is not only doing extremely well so quickly, but it was birthed from someone who has been involved in the community at our level. Someone who has contributed to the progress of Artistic and Creative legislation. I love that so much of the art community at every corner is involved in this and giving it a chance. I wanted to contribute my part to help keep the momentum going. We shape not only the physical world we live in, but the online landscape as well. I encourage everyone to make a stand today and demand the future you want without anyone else's permission. 

Follow me on Cara! ▶ https://cara.app/ergojosh

snippet.title: Back to my roots with Ryobi 3302 installed and printing the same week.

localized.title: Back to my roots with Ryobi 3302 installed and printing the same week.

snippet.title: Print Shop Update, Whats next?
snippet.description: A much needed update on whats going on. There are an infinite number of directions that a business can go in the future and it can be overwhelming. I choose to be excited to see what happens. I'm planning on investing in three areas. Some sort of software to increase efficiency. Additional people to help get work done faster. More printing capacity to speed up printing during busy times. Wohoo!

localized.title: Print Shop Update, Whats next?
localized.description: A much needed update on whats going on. There are an infinite number of directions that a business can go in the future and it can be overwhelming. I choose to be excited to see what happens. I'm planning on investing in three areas. Some sort of software to increase efficiency. Additional people to help get work done faster. More printing capacity to speed up printing during busy times. Wohoo!

snippet.title: Creating the Curl Me Render - Daz Masterclass #42
snippet.description:
See how to build a portrait render with the techniques you've learnt up until this point in the Daz Masterclass! Following on from the previous episode, Jay shows how to pick an outfit for our character, add a pose and expression, adjust clothing, find accessories and make a render with Iray in Daz Studio. Follow along and try it out yourself!

Products used in this demo:
Honni 8: https://www.daz3d.com/honni-8?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821
Olympia 8: https://www.daz3d.com/olympia-8?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821
Sienna HD: https://www.daz3d.com/sienna-hd-for-genesis-8-female?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821
Trending Social Pants: https://www.daz3d.com/trending-socials-pants-for-genesis-8-and-81-females?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821
My Attitude Expressions: https://www.daz3d.com/my-attitude-expressions-for-genesis-81-female?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821
Curl Me Hair: https://www.daz3d.com/curl-me-hair-for-genesis-3-and-8-females?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821

===============

28:00 Rendering the Image

snippet.title: Avoid Poke-Through with the Push Modifier - Daz Masterclass #41
snippet.description:
In this video Jay shows you another way to avoid poke-through using a tool called the Push Modifier. It will let Daz Studio push the surface of an object outwards along the normals. This can be useful to expand an item of clothing away from the figure if it interferes with the figure in multiple places. This is not a perfect solution for every occasion, but may provide value in certain situations. Enjoy!

Anthropomorphic Hippo: https://www.daz3d.com/anthropomorphs--manhippo-hd-for-genesis-8-male?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821
Karate GI Outfit: https://www.daz3d.com/dforce-karate-gi-for-genesis-8?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821

snippet.title: Re-draping Daz clothing with Marvelous Designer - Daz Masterclass #40
snippet.description:
In this episode Jay shows you how we can use Marvelous Designer’s draping engine to get a very accurate fit for our clothing. You can think of this as a dForce engine on steroids. Marvelous Designer is a professional clothing design tool, and it can do much more than what we’re using it for here. Note that it will depend on the clothing item if this process works, and much like with dForce, not every item is compatible with this workflow.

snippet.title: Adjust Clothing with Blender Sculpting Tools - Daz Masterclass #39b
snippet.description:
Continuing on from the previous video, Jay us going to smooth out the Librarian Outfit with Blender's sculpting tools. Most sculpting brushes are available in both ZBrush and Blender, although they are named slightly differently. We'll give you a quick tour of the Blender Sculpting tools and how to use them. We’ll remove distortions on the blouse, smooth out the under-bust area, and add some wrinkles to create a realistic look. 

Watch Jay's live stream about how to adjust clothing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t7_mkD3-wZQ

00:00 Introduction to Sculpting Tools in Blender
04:00 Smoothing out the Underbust Area
06:00 Enabling the Wireframe Overlay
10:00 Adding Wrinkles with the Cloth Brush

snippet.title: Adjusting Clothing with the Blender Vertex Tools - Daz Masterclass #39a
snippet.description:
In this video, Jay explains how to use Blender's excellent vertex tools to fit Genesis clothing. We’ll explain how to exchange data with Daz Studio, basic navigation in Blender, and how to make adjustments to clothing items. 
For this example we’ll use the auto-fitted Librarian outfit from the previous session, and our aim is to make the sleeves a little longer. 

00:00 Session Overview
02:00 Exporting Objects for Blender
07:00 Viewport Navigation in Blender
09:40 Editing Mode and using the Vertex Tools
12:50 Creating an Edge Loop Selection
15:00 Soft Selections in Blender (Proportional Editing)
19:20 Bringing the Shirt back into Daz Studio

snippet.title: Adjusting Clothing with ZBrush - Daz Masterclass #38
snippet.description:
ZBrush is a digital sculpting tool that lets us make organic changes to figures, clothing, and hair. In this video, Jay shows you how ZBrush integrates seamlessly with Daz Studio and how you can make changes that can be brought back with a single click. We’ll discuss navigation in ZBrush, sculpt brushes, and basic sculpting techniques.

For this example, Jay is using an auto-fitted blouse that clings onto the body too much to be believable. We’ll smooth it out for a more natural look, and we’ll take care of tucking hair underneath a pair of glasses our model wears on her head. 

i13 Librarian Outfit for G3 (auto-fitted to G8): https://www.daz3d.com/i13-librarian-outfit-for-the-genesis-3-female-s?cjref=1&utm_source=cj&utm_medium=affiliate&cjevent=8562606683d811ec82acee370a82b821

00:00 ZBrush and Session Overview
02:50 Sending a Figure and Clothing to ZBrush
04:40 Viewport Navigation in ZBrush
07:00 Smoothing out the Underbust Area
12:00 Fixing the Underarm Area
16:50 Fixing the Hair underneath her Glasses

snippet.title: Adjusting Clothing with Hexagon - Daz Masterclass #37
snippet.description:
In this video, Jay gives you an introduction to Daz 3D’s Hexagon application. It’s a stand-alone 3D modeler that’s tightly integrated with Daz Studio. I’ll show you how to navigate the viewport, send data over from Daz Studio and bring it back, and how to make simple changes to props and clothing. I will also go into detail on how to customize morph sliders as you create them, and how to enable the advanced Hexagon bridge options. 

With practice, Hexagon will become an indispensable tool to create your images. You can download the 32-bit release version of Hexagon here. A 64-bit Beta Version is available through Install Manager and Daz Central (enable the Public Build filter to download it). 

Hexagon 64-bit Beta: https://www.daz3d.com/hexagon-beta
Max Hancock's Hexagon Toolbox: https://maxhancock.co/the-hexagon-3d-toolbox/
Vladimir Chopine's Hexagon Tutorials: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=azlWFMlxtkY&list=PLaH1PMiI_7AgHQgTiGoE2-Y2_kCWbPl2L
Our own Hexagon quick tips: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UmSe_sAhUvs&list=PLF3LSR7D48Me0rix6kdS5BL5ZycpNxA71

snippet.title: Adjusting Daz Content with External Tools (Intro) - Daz Masterclass #36
snippet.description:
To make 3D objects our own in any situation, we may want to make changes to props, clothing, and characters with external 3D modeling apps. In this introduction, I’ll discuss how we can do this using Morph Targets, which will assure that both rigging and material data will remain intact in Daz Studio. 

In this video, Jay shows you the concept in principle using a tool called Morph Loader. In subsequent videos I’ll show you how it works in detail.

snippet.title: Full animation tutorial in Blender
snippet.description:
Let’s create a full shot in Blender 3D including animation, 2D VFX with grease pencil, background, lighting, rendering and compositing. The trick is to be as effective as possible, figuring out what’s is the priority to make it looks good (… it’s the pose and framing!).

snippet.title: Auto Setup and Importing Animations to Unity | ActorCore Asset Store
snippet.description:
Get FREE 3D characters and motions: https://actorcore.reallusion.com/

ActorCore is Reallusion’s browser-based service that provides a huge library of high-quality 3D characters and mocap motions. Designed for crowd scene usage, ActorCore's lightweight characters are fully-rigged for facial, body and lip-sync animations, suitable from long to middle camera ranges. Along with an extensive library of 3D motions, and FBX file export formats compatible with all major 3D tools including Unreal Engine, Unity, Blender, 3ds Max, Maya, MotionBuilder, Cinema4D, and iClone, ActorCore is the best 3D content marketplace for real-time animation and business simulations.

Unity Auto Setup provides a powerful pipeline for the intuitive workflow between iClone/Character Creator/ActorCore and Unity.  In this video, we’ll look at some of the basic options for bringing characters and motions from Reallusion into Unity, as well as basic motion editing and retargeting of custom models.

00:00 Intro
00:23 Character Import with Unity Auto Setup
01:13 Animation Preview & Adjustment
02:54 Animation in Gameplay Mode
04:24 Applying Animations to Characters
05:45 Retargeting Animations to Unity Characters

*Note: Assets shown in this tutorial serve only as reference material.

snippet.title: Innovating the Future of 3D Animation Education at Creative Media Industries Institute (CMII)
snippet.description:
https://magazine.reallusion.com/2024/06/04/innovating-the-future-of-3d-animation-education-at-cmii/ The Creative Media Industries Institute (CMII) has been at the forefront of integrating cutting-edge technology into its curriculum, ensuring that students are well-prepared for the dynamic world of media and entertainment.

Professor James Martin's approach to teaching 3D Animation (CMIS 4160) is a testament to how modern tools can revolutionize education. Using Reallusion iClone software, Martin introduces students, many of whom are first-time animators, to animation through practical, real-world production scenarios. The course is structured around three comprehensive modules: Character Animation, Crowd-Simulation creation, and Motion Capture Animation cleanup.

00:00 Introduction
00:54 Professor James Martin
01:08 Background and Course Focus
01:17 16 Week Course in 3D Animation
01:35 Professor Martin on iClone in the Classroom
02:03 3 Modules for teaching 3D Animation with iClone
02:12 1st Module Game Design Concept Short
02:39 2nd Module Crowd Simulation
03:03 3rd Module Motion Capture Cleanup
04:01 Syllabus Overview for CMIS 4160 3D Animation
08:02 Extending the Classroom with Discord
09:41 Student Animations Module 1 - Game Concept short
13:36 Student Animations Module 2 - Crowd Simulation
16:01 Student Animations Module 3 - Motion Capture Cleanup
23:47 Professor Martin’s Closing Statements
24:49 Reallusion Educator Specials and Free Semester Offer

snippet.title: Recreating Dragon Ball Vegeta with ZBrush Face Tools & Character Creator
snippet.description:
https://magazine.reallusion.com/2024/06/27/recreating-dragon-ball-vegeta-with-zbrush-face-tools-character-creator/ Join seasoned 3D artist Arnoldo Atencio Vazquez as he recreates the iconic Dragon Ball character Vegeta. With his expert skills in ZBrush, Arnoldo seamlessly integrates Character Creator with the ZBrush Face Tools plugin, transforming Vegeta into an expressive and animation-ready 3D character. After refining the facial expressions, he meticulously adds textures, accessories, and wrinkles for the final render.

Arnoldo’s diverse portfolio includes designing custom maxillofacial prosthetics for 3D printing, collaborating on virtual and augmented reality experiences, and contributing to indie game development. His dedication and passion for 3D art have propelled him to excel in the industry, continually pushing the boundaries of his craft. You can follow Arnoldo's profile with the following link.

snippet.title: Learn CC GoZ Plus from the master - Bake body, clothing, accessories, props with ZBrush in one click
snippet.description:
https://rebrand.ly/711e95 In this tutorial, Michael Pavlovich will demonstrate the features of CC GoZ Plus, including converting base color maps and normal maps in Character Creator to polypaint and detail layers in ZBrush, and sending polypaint and high-res details from ZBrush to Character Creator as baked color and normal maps, respectively.

This technique can be used for props, clothing, accessories, and more! Michael also uses this in conjunction with ZBrush Pose Tools to pose high-res source assets for 3D printing.

Learn more:
CC GoZ Plus https://rebrand.ly/711e95

snippet.title: Typographics 2022: Book Report Footnoted with Lorraine Wild
snippet.description:
This talk took place on June 18, 2022 in The Great Hall at The Cooper Union as part of Typographics Conference. The livestreaming, recording and archiving of the event was made possible by the generous support of Google Fonts.

A look at three different books designed by Green Dragon Office (and published in the pandemic) that reflect this design office’s obsessions with history, genre and narrative structure.

Lorraine Wild is a graphic designer in Los Angeles. Her design firm, Green Dragon Office, focuses on collaborative work with artists, architects, curators, editors and publishers. In addition, she serves as the Creative Design Consultant to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, consulting on publications, exhibitions, and design for public outreach. She is a member of the faculty of the California Institute of the Arts. Wild received the AIGA Gold Medal in 2006. Recent projects include the design of books and exhibition catalogues for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Cranbrook Academy Art Museum, and the Kestner Gesellschaft in Hannover. She is a graduate of the Cranbrook Academy of Art and the Yale School of Art.

Home: greendragonoffice.com
Instagram: @wildlosangeles

snippet.title: Typographics 2022: Graphic Design Is Easy with Yotam Hadar
snippet.description:
This talk took place on June 18, 2022 in The Great Hall at The Cooper Union as part of Typographics Conference. The livestreaming, recording and archiving of the event was made possible by the generous support of Google Fonts.

“Graphic Design is Easy” is an attempt to articulate a design process that rejects overthinking and embraces obvious, lazy, and reductive ideas. It stems from the belief that there might be unique clarity in the first idea that comes to mind in a given situation. Situation=inspiration, Context=content.

Yotam Hadar is a graphic designer, typographer and educator, interested in the potential of subtle gestures to create meaning and impact. He spent the last 15 years collaborating with clients and studios like Nike, Apple, Prada, Movement Research, Pentagram, Project Projects, 2x4 and Sagmeister & Walsh to create work across print, branding, environmental and interactive design that won accolades from the ADC, TDC, Tokyo TDC, Chaumont Festival, Graphis, and Brand New Awards, among others. A design educator since 2009, Yotam taught design and typography at Yale School of Art, Pratt Institute, Parsons School of Design and Rutgers University, and was a guest critic at RISD, SVA and NYU.

Home: yotamhadar.com
Twitter: @Yotam
Instagram: @yotamh

snippet.title: Typographics 2022: Kinetic Visual Identity with Rosie Garschina
snippet.description:
This talk took place on June 17, 2022 in The Great Hall at The Cooper Union as part of Typographics Conference. The livestreaming, recording and archiving of the event was made possible by the generous support of Google Fonts.

A look into visual identities that utilize kinetic type systems to resonate and breakthrough. Rosie Garschina will explore the process behind building brands that utilize signature behaviors as a foundational element. She will show how creative tools can activate brands to embody a unique and memorable personality. Case studies will include the recent transformation of Paramount’s BET, the launch of streaming service AMC+, the refresh of Paramount’s TeenNick, and a newly minted kinetic identity for Sesame Street.

Rosie Garschina is a multi-disciplinary creative director with a 15-year tenure working in brand experience. She has helped brands such as Amazon, Apple, Spotify and Paramount develop smart and visually compelling solutions that create clarity and distinction.

Prior to Trollbäck+Company she was Creative Director at Interbrand NY and Sibling Rivalry leading large-scale rebrands and 360 campaigns. Most recently she led a reinvention of the entire BET ecosystem including BET+, BET Her, BET Jams and BET Soul. In 2019 she rebranded Viacom’s TeenNick which BrandNew named one of the top rebrands of the year. In 2018 she directed a global campaign for Spotify Premium that doubled their paid subscriber base and elevated the premium platform.

Passionate about the ability of design to transform business and culture, for four years she served on the Executive board of AIGA/NY curating events and experiences that emotionally resonated with the NY design community and their values. She is active speaking and judging around the country.

Home: garschina.com
Twitter: @rosegarsch
Instagram: @rosiegarschina

AI in Libraries, a Conversation

snippet.title: Quality Indicators for Open Educational Resources (OER)
snippet.description:
Join us for our first event in the Resourcefully Assessing — Critical Approaches to Assessment series, hosted by the Outreach & Assessment working group. This series will explore a variety of assessment strategies for different resource and collection types. In this coffee chat, Joanna Schimizzi will discuss quality indicators for Open Educational Resources (OER). We’ll share example resources, rubrics, and templates that support you in finding and evaluating OER, with a focus on primary source sets. Part of the conversation will of course focus on student needs and on the opportunity to customize and localize resources to build robust sets of work.

Joanna Schimizzi is a Biology teacher in North Carolina and a Professional Learning Specialist with ISKME. While getting her Master’s in Education from Northeastern University, she became extremely interested in classroom culture and student identity. This led her to work with ISKME and OER Commons to support educators in finding Open Educational Resources (OER) so that resources can be modified and remixed to include a wider variety of perspectives and experiences. Joanna is mom to two boys and lives with her husband in a little town outside of Charlotte, NC.

Slides: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vQ4dOXfuv99z74g-s74UcJKviVP2hZMVr5A8fDsKf6LKA7F6UlUIrDI_e_FZYyzprYM4iY5SGlSDcgQ/pub

snippet.title: Reconciling Metadata with OpenRefine
snippet.description:
Does your metadata contain values that don’t align with controlled vocabularies commonly used in the GLAM sector? Learn how to reconcile metadata with OpenRefine, a popular data cleaning tool that can help you with metadata prep for DPLA. The Outreach & Assessment and Metadata Working Groups invite you to join this session, which builds upon February’s Introduction to OpenRefine presentation. Attendees will:

- Understand the basics of reconciliation with OpenRefine
- See examples of reconciliation with commonly used vocabularies such as the Art & Architecture Thesaurus™
- Get pointers on untangling data, such as removing duplicate values

This meeting will be led by Helen Baer, Digital Projects Librarian at Colorado State University, a member of the Plains to Peaks Collective. No software pre-installation will be required by participants. Please feel free to reach out to Helen if you have specific use cases or controlled vocabularies you’d like her to focus on at this event.

snippet.title: Introduction to Standardized Rights Statements
snippet.description:
Curious about standardized rights statements? Standardized rights statements help increase access and reuse of your items. By providing rights in the form of a machine-readable URI, users can facet on rights in the DPLA interface and open access items can be shared by DPLA to Wikimedia Commons. Want to learn how to apply them to your digital collection?

Join the DPLA Rights Statements Working Group for an introduction to standardized rights statements. RightsStatements.org statements are a simple, standardized system of labels that more clearly communicate the copyright and re-use status of digital objects to the public. Adding these labels to your digital collections will improve usability and access for users. Presenters for this webinar will include members of the DPLA Rights Statements Working Group, many of whom are currently implementing rights statements for the collections they manage. They will share their expertise and experiences, as well as a wide range of resources for implementation.

snippet.title: Special Projects in Reparative and Inclusive Description
snippet.description:
In this final workshop of the series, presenters will share how they approached description projects for special collections at their universities. Projects include: reparative description for Nazi publications identified in the collection and expanding access to electronic agricultural extension reports through non-English language subject headings. A final presentation is not included in the recording at the speakers' request.

Presenters
- Julie Moore, Special Collections Catalog Librarian, Fresno State University. Julie has been a catalog librarian in a variety of libraries and states for over 30 years. She is especially well-known for cataloging special formats (3-dimensional objects, in particular.) Her current research interest is in critical/inclusive/ethical/reparative cataloging. She was a Task Force member for OLAC Best Practices for Cataloging DVD-Video and Blu-ray Discs, Objects, Streaming Media, and Video Games and wrote a chapter in the upcoming publication, Inclusive Cataloging: Histories, Context, and Reparative Approaches (2024). Julie is the recipient of the Margaret Mann Citation (2020) and the OLAC Nancy B. Olson Award (2010). 
- Vance Woods, Lead Cataloger, Cataloging and Government Documents Unit, Oregon State University Libraries and Press. Vance has a Master’s degree in church-state studies from Baylor University in Texas, with a focus on medieval Celtic history in the British Isles. He started as a special collections cataloger at Baylor in 2009, moving to Oregon State University in 2017 after an interim period in Argentina, where he grew up. He has extensive experience with original cataloging in many different formats, both physical and electronic, including rare and unique materials. He is an expert in languages, having worked with Baylor’s Keston Collection, comprised of materials from and about the former Soviet Union in a wide variety of languages, including several Cyrillic-based languages, and is fascinated by linguistics in the bibliographic field; it’s a passion he continues to develop at Oregon State. He has published in both scholarly and popular contexts, including a photographic history of Bates County, Missouri, his family’s ancestral home.

He is an expert in languages, having worked with Baylor’s Keston Collection, comprised of materials from and about the former Soviet Union in a wide variety of languages, including several Cyrillic-based languages, and is fascinated by linguistics in the bibliographic field; it’s a passion he continues to develop at Oregon State. He has published in both scholarly and popular contexts, including a photographic history of Bates County, Missouri, his family’s ancestral home.

snippet.title: Local Contexts: Tools for Supporting Indigenous Rights and Interests in Collections
snippet.description:
Every Indigenous community has cultural and biological knowledge within educational systems, archives, libraries, and museums that they do not own, do not control, and cannot govern circulation over. Local Contexts is a global nonprofit organization that was founded to address the needs of Indigenous communities and local organizations who wanted a practical method to deal with the range of intellectual property issues that arise in relation to managing cultural heritage materials. The Local Contexts Traditional Knowledge and Biocultural Labels and Notices are tools for Indigenous communities and collections- and research-based institutions to support Indigenous cultural authority and data sovereignty. In this webinar, which is being hosted by the DPLA Rights Statements Working Group, the Local Contexts team will introduce the Labels and Notices and how they can be used to support Indigenous rights and interests in collections and data.

Presenters

- Dr. Stephany RunningHawk Johnson is a Citizen of the Oglala Lakota Nation and the Local Contexts Founding Executive Director. Stephany was previously an Assistant Professor in Cultural Studies and Social Thought in Education at Washington State University. Her scholarship examines the limitations and possibilities of decolonizing approaches to science education in schools, and explores how changes in educational policy and practice that center Indigenous knowledges and ways of knowing have a positive impact.
- Corrie Roe is the Local Contexts Director of Outreach and Strategy. In her role, Corrie supports Indigenous communities, institutions, and researchers to learn about and adopt the Local Contexts system. Corrie is a settler living on Paugussett and Wappinger Homelands with a background in anthropology and museum studies.
- Emily Santhanam is a citizen of the Chickasaw Nation and the Local Contexts Outreach Coordinator (Americas). Within this role, Emily supports multifaceted outreach efforts by cultivating and sustaining Local Contexts’ network of Indigenous communities, institutions, and researchers. Prior to her involvement with Local Contexts, Emily worked in multiple curatorial and research capacities for cultural organizations and museums across the country.

snippet.title: Representations of Gender and Sexuality in Metadata
snippet.description:
Practical Approaches to Reparative Description Workshop Series: Representations of Gender and Sexuality in Metadata
Thursday, April 18, 2024, at 1p ET

Capturing information about gender and sexuality in descriptive metadata often surfaces questions and unique considerations about how to effectively maximize exposure of diverse collections without mislabeling or putting members of vulnerable communities at increased risk. At this presentation, attendees will hear a variety of perspectives on strategies for how to approach the capture of this information, as well as how to implement existing resources to help enhance collection metadata.

Presenters:
- As University of Washington’s Special Collections Digital Collections Curator, Ann Lally is involved in the processing and arrangement of incoming digital materials as well as curation and quality assurance of the web archiving program.  Ann has been working at the UW with digital projects as a project manager, consultant, and active participant since 2003. Ann has been an active participant in local and regional metadata and usability initiatives. Before coming to the UW, Ann worked as the Associate Director of the Artificial Intelligence Lab at the University of Arizona in Tucson.
- Bri Watson (@brimwats) is a disabled, white, queer & nonbinary settler living in Musqueam, Tsleil-Waututh, and Squamish. They are currently a Vanier Scholar at University of British Columbia’s iSchool focusing on histories of information and the practice of equitable cataloging in libraries, archives, museums, and special collections. Watson is the Archivist-Historian of the American Psychological Association’s Consensual Nonmonogamy Committee (div44cnm.org) and the Haslam Collection on Polyamory at the Kinsey Institute. They serve on the editorial board of Homosaurus (homosaurus.org), an international linked data vocabulary for queer terminology.
- Michael L. Stewart (they/them) is a Metadata Librarian at the University of Delaware and the Metadata Specialist for the NJ/DE Digital Collective, a regional hub of DPLA. They currently serve as the chair of the Program for Cooperative Cataloging’s (PCC) Task Group on Gender (TGOG), as well as in a liaison role from this group to the PCC’s Task Group on Privacy in Name Authority Records.

snippet.title: Crowdsourcing the Archives - March 14, 2024
snippet.description: In this presentation, National Archives Catalog Community Managers Nancy Sullivan and Suzanne Isaacs introduced the National Archives’ Citizen Archivist program. snippet.title: CES 2024 - Raspberry Pi CEO Eben Upton on the evolution of his platform
snippet.description: In this video, John Skabardonis from Covestro speaks with Eben Upton, CEO of Raspberry PI. Upton notes how the use of Raspberry Pi hardware has evolved from prototyping into production. Their low cost computing hardware enables designers and engineers to deploy intelligence into the world at a much higher density than previously possible, opening the doors to a an opportunity-rich environment for innovation. Covestro's thermally conductive polycarbonate helps dissipate the heat generated by increasingly powerful PCBs.

snippet.title: CES 2024 - Altair Digital Twin technology
snippet.description: In this video, John Skabardonis from Covestro speaks with Ismail Benhayoun, Senior Technical Director for Product Design at Altair. Here they review a demo combining simulation, high-performance computing and AI to produce a 'digital twin' model of a product. Using Altair technologies, designers can combine photo-realistic visuals with high fidelity data models to trace the lifetime usage of a product and predict maintenance failures or point out any possible improvements to the design.

snippet.title: Designing Better Closed Captions UX - WORDS 2023
snippet.description:
Vitaly Friedman, Creative Lead of Smashing Magazine and UX consultant for European Parliament, shares valuable insights into how captions and subtitles can enhance accessibility and improve the user experience for all. Learn about best practices for captioning guidelines, the differences between subtitles and captions, and the importance of considering environmental impact. You'll come away with a better understanding of how to make your content more accessible and user-friendly for everyone."

snippet.title: UX Writing: How Boring Text Can Wake Up Your Users - WORDS 2023
snippet.description:
Discover the power of "boring" copy in UX writing with Yossi Nachemi, UX Writer at Google/Waze. In this engaging talk from UX Salon WORDS 2023, Yossi discusses the importance of clear and consistent copy, debunking the myth that all copy needs to be exciting. Learn when to switch things up and when to embrace the tried-and-true phrases that users understand and appreciate. Don't miss this insightful perspective on effective UX writing!

snippet.description:

The release of Eevee 2.0 in Blender 4.2 has sparked a fascinating debate within the 3D community: Could this enhanced real-time render engine possibly replace Cycles? In this video, we delve deep into the capabilities, improvements, and potential implications of Eevee 2.0, comparing it directly with Cycles to see how they stack up against each other.

Eevee 2.0 brings significant upgrades, offering near real-time rendering speeds with improved lighting and shadow fidelity, which makes it a tempting option for many projects. However, Cycles, known for its path-tracing capabilities that provide photorealistic results, holds its ground in scenarios where ultimate realism is paramount.

Join us as we explore use cases, performance benchmarks, and visual quality comparisons between Eevee 2.0 and Cycles. This analysis will help both new and seasoned Blender users understand the strengths and limitations of each engine, guiding you in choosing the right tool for your specific needs in Blender 4.2.

#blender #blendertutorial #blender3d

snippet.title: How to Rig Any Car in 10 Minutes without Addons | Blender 3D
snippet.description:
Check out PolyCam now and try out a free trial here: https://apps.apple.com/app/apple-store/id1532482376?pt=122128498&ct=SouthernShotty&mt=8

Point Cloud Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@mv_nyc

Free Car Model: https://sketchfab.com/3d-models/low-poly-car-classic-coupe-c90aef909b794a62ae8379fcd7ae4134

Free Eye Texture: https://www.patreon.com/posts/106689306?pr=true

Get ready to turbocharge your 3D car animations! This Blender tutorial is all about efficiency and effectiveness, showing you how to rig any car model in just 10 minutes without the need for any additional addons.

Follow along as we break down the rigging process into simple steps that even beginners can understand and apply. You'll learn how to use Blender’s native tools to create a functional car rig that can handle turns, acceleration, and all the essential movements needed to bring your vehicle to life in any scene.

By the end of this tutorial, not only will you have a fully rigged car ready for animation, but you'll also gain valuable rigging skills that can be applied to other models in your future projects. Let’s put the pedal to the metal and start rigging!

Prepare to be amazed by the capabilities of the latest shader in Blender 4.2! This groundbreaking tool isn't just an update—it's a revolution in the way we think about and create visual effects in 3D environments. In this video, we explore the insane potential of this new shader that lets you create realistic portals, dynamic reflections, and much more.

We'll dive deep into a hands-on tutorial where you'll learn how to harness the power of this new shader to craft mesmerizing portals that look like they're straight out of a sci-fi movie. From setting up the basic shader nodes to fine-tuning the effects for maximum impact, we'll cover all the steps necessary to bring these fantastical elements into your projects.

#3DModeling #BlenderTutorial #VisualEffects

snippet.title: Blender vs. the VFX industry ft. Henning and Morton from FlippedNormals
snippet.description:
Featured image from Barnstorm VFX - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYAccCoxSiQ

Check out the show notes and more information here https://b3d.cgcookie.com/n6r7vv

Listen to all 7 episodes of Denoise Season 1 here: https://b3d.cgcookie.com/4wn2r5

Stay tuned!  Season 2 recorded live at BCON LA drops in July.

Blender’s recent surge in popularity has not shown any signs of slowing. As artists pick it up for the first time and discover how powerful it is, they often wonder whether it's capable of being used to create their favorite movies, games, and shows.

Recently, Kent Trammell and Jason van Gumster, two of our Blender experts here at CG Cookie, sat down with the visual effects pros Henning Sanden and Morten Jaeger of FlippedNormals to talk about Blender’s place in the industry.

Henning Sanden - https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8218979/
Morten Jaeger - https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6173018/

snippet.title: Fueling Artistic Creativity: Insights from 3D Artists
snippet.description:
Check out the show notes and more information here https://b3d.cgcookie.com/m9q63s

Listen to all 7 episodes of Denoise Season 1 here: https://b3d.cgcookie.com/mqjwv6

Creativity is, at its essence, a type of problem-solving. It is fundamental to our work as 3D artists and needs to be cultivated over time.

Not everyone goes about that the same way. The CG Cookie Blender instructors Wayne, Kent, and Jonathan recently talked about their journeys in creativity.  In this episode they share where their inspiration comes from and how we deal with creative blocks when they inevitably arise.

snippet.title: Rookie Blender Mistakes We All Make
snippet.description:
Check out the show notes and full description on CG Cookie:  https://b3d.cgcookie.com/mk1fcx

Listen to all 7 episodes of Denoise Season 1 here: https://b3d.cgcookie.com/slqx2k

Stay tuned!  Season 2 recorded live at BCON LA drops in July.  Subscribe to be notified.

If you're getting into Blender, avoiding common mistakes upfront will help you learn faster and save time in the long run. 

There are two types of mistakes when using Blender: technical and creative. The first are accidental button presses or overlooked settings and the second are incorrect approaches to a problem. After a few decades of experience with Blender, we've seen plenty of both and can help you work through them as you learn. 

In this episode we talk with CG Cookie Instructor Assistant Martin and Chris Bailey from Animal Logic who you also see as a tutorial instructor on our CG Cookie YouTube page.  

Check out Chris's course Bug Bots here: https://b3d.cgcookie.com/jt6io4

snippet.title: Hard Surface Modeling Tips - Better Boolean Subtractions in Blender
snippet.description:
Check out my course 3D Cars: Inside and Out on Gumroad, Blender Market, and Flipped Normals.
Gumroad - https://cgmasters.gumroad.com/l/3d-cars
Blender Market - https://www.blendermarket.com/products/3d-cars-inside-and-out-in-blender
Flipped Normals - https://flippednormals.com/product/3d-cars-inside-and-out-in-blender-32469?dst=b8XbGnH5

In this tutorial I'll give you a couple tips on how to get better results from the Boolean modifier. A lot can go wrong when you're creating cutouts with the Boolean modifier, but there are some useful solutions like changing the Solver, Overlap Threshold, and even modifying the cutout object to provide extra geometry to fix shading issues.

Check out https://cgmasters.com for more courses and tutorials.

snippet.title: 3D Cars: Inside and Out in Blender - Available Now!
snippet.description:
Check out the course on Gumroad here - https://cgmasters.gumroad.com/l/3d-cars

Or on Blender Market here - https://www.blendermarket.com/products/3d-cars-inside-and-out-in-blender

Here we go again, but this time the course is bigger, better, and there’s a whole lot of new stuff, including a full interior. My past car modeling training has been studied by industry giants like Hyundai and Volvo, as well as designers in top gaming and film companies all over the world. And now I’ve taken those techniques and made them even better. In this step-by-step course we’ll tackle an amazing car design by professional designer Lee Rosario, and I’ll show you new ways to solve even the trickiest hard surface challenges with ease as we build this awesome car together from the first vertex to the final renders.

So join me in this car creation journey, and learn tons of techniques for hard surface modeling, shading, rendering, and compositing, all inside the free open source 3D software, Blender.

Thank you all for supporting my training, and if you check this one out I hope you like it!

And if you want to check out more of Lee's design work, you can see his projects here - https://www.behance.net/leerosario

snippet.title: Procedural Parallax Effect in Blender
snippet.description:
Learn how to create a procedural parallax effect using shader nodes in this Blender tutorial. Parallax mapping is a technique used to give a 2 dimensional surface a truly 3 dimensional look. It's different than bump mapping and normal mapping because parallax mapping creates the illusion of depth, not just surface detail. And this depth is based on the perspective too, creating a convincing 3 dimensional feel from every angle. This shader was originally made for this tutorial by Erindale Woodford. Check out more of his work here - https://linktr.ee/erindale.xyz

Download the project files here -
https://cgmasters.com/tutorials/parallax.zip

Check out the course Master Procedural Texturing in Blender -
https://www.blendermarket.com/products/master-procedural-texturing-in-blender

Check out https://cgmasters.com for more courses and tutorials.

snippet.title: 5 Awesome Procedural Texturing Tricks in Blender
snippet.description:
Check out our course "Master Procedural Texturing in Blender" here - https://www.blendermarket.com/products/master-procedural-texturing-in-blender

Download this tutorial's resource files here - https://cgmasters.com/tutorials/5_Awesome_Tricks.zip

In this tutorial I'll show you 5 awesome procedural texturing tricks that'll really come in handy for various situations. These tricks include rounding off tile corners, using linear light to distort textures without moving them out of place, directional and full blur effects for any texture node, and how to automatically round off angular beveled edges.

Check out https://cgmasters.com for more courses and tutorials.

snippet.title: Master Procedural Texturing in Blender | Out Now!
snippet.description:
Check it out here - https://www.blendermarket.com/products/master-procedural-texturing-in-blender

Tap into the unlimited potential of Blender’s incredibly powerful node editor, and learn how to create advanced and highly customizable procedural textures from scratch. In this course I’ll walk you through building complex textures, step by step. You’ll learn about a ton of different nodes and creative ways you can combine them to achieve amazing results.

We’ll focus on two big projects in this course, highly customizable Subway Tiles and an animated and customizable Lava Field. Both are fun and complex projects that will give us a good mix of both technical and organic styles of textures.

For this course I teamed up with procedural texture master Erindale Woodford. Erin created the textures and I created the training. We chose these specific topics to focus on important texture building skills like technical planning and texture layering to help you gain a strong understanding of how to approach and achieve complexity.

snippet.title: Blender for Complete and Total Beginners
snippet.description:
Blender for Complete and Total Beginners is the best starting point for anyone interested in learning 3D and Blender. Check out the course page to learn more - https://cgmasters.com/blender-for-complete-and-total-beginners/

Blender is perfect for anyone interested in learning 3D, because it’s incredibly powerful and free. This full creation suite offers a complete range of artistic possibilities, including modeling, animation, rendering, compositing, video editing, and a lot more. So whether you’re interested in creating games, producing animations, 3D printing, or anything else related to 3D, Blender has you covered with it’s complete production toolkit.

Learning such an advanced piece of software can be intimidating though. There are a crazy amount of tools and it can be tricky to figure out where to start. That’s what this course is for. This curriculum was designed to give you a clear understanding of the most fundamental concepts and tools, even if you have zero experience.

snippet.title: Blender Tutorial - Physically Based Rendering (PBR) and the Principled Node
snippet.description:
The Blender Encyclopedia is finally out! See more about it here - https://cgmasters.com/the-blender-encyclopedia/

This tutorial is from our course, The Blender Encyclopedia. This course is a comprehensive reference guide for the software and includes step by step projects for all skill levels.

In this free lecture from the course we'll be diving deep into the Principled BSDF shader node, which is an all-in-one type node that can be used to create a ton of realistic materials such as wood, metal, marble, cloth, glass, and so much more.

In order to understand this node better we'll also go over PBR, or Physically Based Rendering, where I'll introduce you to the scientific basis for building physically accurate materials. PBR simply refers to simulating how light and materials behave in reality, and the principled node automatically does some scientific calculations to achieve this realism, So it's extremely useful when looking to create believable materials.

The final blend files and infographics are available in the course's resource files.

Textures used in the thumbnail are from Texture Haven (https://texturehaven.com) and are released under Creative Commons 0.

Check out https://cgmasters.com for more courses and tutorials.

snippet.title: Video Thursday Q&A July 11th 2024
snippet.description:
Submit your questions anytime https://www.askofficehours.global
Join our global community https://officehours.global

00:00:00 Intro
00:01:08 If using six Source Four LED lights in a covered, outdoor stage, have portable battery units advanced enough to consider as substitute for generator truck? It's a one hour event (plus reharsals)
00:04:03 A client has a budget of $2500 for to me to get him the best camera setup that can be permanently set at his Mac computer to record courses via Zoom. Recommendations for Camera/lights/capture? id like abilty to adjust all things via remote on Zoom.
00:12:02 Any experience with some of vimeo's newer tools like their editor, teleprompter, etc?
00:17:09 When setting up a installation or live production what is your go to video or audio track you use to test and why?
00:21:02 Sony announced the ZV-E10 II yesterday. It features the same sensor as the FX30, LUT support, S-Cinetone, 10bit 4.2.2 recording, etc. for less than $1k. Thoughts?
00:25:15 when doing live audio gigs outside in the high heat of triple digits are there any big fan brand or style difference to keep crew safe and cool?
00:33:15 Do YouTube just break Downie?
00:34:52 Please comment on the new Vizrt PTZ3 PLUS and PTZ3 UHD PLUS cameras. Vizrt brings the BroadcastAV market sharply into focus with today’s launch. Bridging the gap between ProAV and Broadcast.
00:39:57 Here’s a fun/strange question. I want to livestream from an arcade and have seen streams that use devices to capture the screen from Ms. Pac Man (or other older arcade games) and split the signal between the console and HDMI. What would achieve this?
00:46:52 a question about mixers....are there any brands or types to avoid in live audio production, as a newer person to live audio bands?
00:49:22 Looks like a 16 gauge extension cord is not beefy enough for 14,000 BTU AC. Wire felt like it was melting and extremely hot to touch. Destroyed Furman power strip permanently. Thoughts?
00:52:05 When a corporate PC connected to corporate WiFi has an ATEM connected to it by USB, the Wifi gets cut off. Doesn't happen on non-corporate Wifi or corporate ethernet connection. How to keep ATEM from being seen as network device invader?
00:54:37 Interesting article: BBC UK Election ingesting 369 live feeds into a Cloud Production Workflow [link]

00:54:37 Interesting article: BBC UK Election ingesting 369 live feeds into a Cloud Production Workflow [link]

snippet.title: Audio Wednesday Q&A - July 10th - Preventing radio station interference in audio systems
snippet.description:
Behringer, Allen and Heath, Yamaha, DigiCo... there are so many options! We'll discuss what console mixers are best for what event.

Submit your questions anytime https://www.askofficehours.global
Join our global community https://officehours.global

00:00 Intro
00:00:48 I am consider a Zoom mic change. Thoughts on Shure Beta 87a in supercardioid for spoken word? Or is that really a mic for singing? Thanks!
00:04:45 My audio is out of sync. I have a X32 -} MixPre6 -} Mac and Cam -} ATEM -} Mac. When I adjust audio delay on the X32 mic channel, I get an echo. Is there a diff place to adjust delay? 
[link]
00:09:42 If you were buying large bare hard drives (above 15 TB) to use for media, what would you buy and where would you buy them from?
00:12:19 Alex, with all the technology and expertise around us each day, do you think that Office Hours is getting any better at singing together? Happy Birthday, by the way!
00:13:46 When Unreal Engine is used in a live environment, is there a frontend that handles loading/unloading scenes and managing UE, or is there typically a dedicated UE operator?
00:15:08 Industry disruption. Video editing and production jobs on upwork have gone up 39% since ChatGPT was released. Discuss [link]
00:19:52 Tascam Mixcast 4 via usb-c to Macbook pro. PodMic usb via XLR and Sennheiser headphones, all attached to the Mixcast. I am picking up an FM radio station...and not a good one. Help!
00:35:36 Should OH apply for the creator conference deadline July 12 [link]
00:35:55 When will ZOOM open up 1080p for individuals utilizing the "Pro" tier? What is the barrier?
00:37:03 Weird problem. I have chrome routed to loopback to Dante virtual soundcard to X32rack to speakers. Works great until I click on the (i) button on messages to see find friends and audio stops. Loopback still shows audio but nothing from DVS.
00:40:29 Can anyone recommend a good audio adapter for aviation headsets for recording in-flight conversations? I have a Tascam DR-40 recorder that has XLR inputs. I'm also open to purchasing a dedicated recorder for this purpose.
00:41:53 A colleague hired a guest speaker who does not allow his talk to be recorded. I’m told this is normal in some countries. What’s the best approach to booking guests and who ultimately controls the broadcast rights for events?
00:51:22 Morning Everyone! Sony just announced the ZV E-10 II, would this be a better option than the mark 1 for mobile kits?

[link]
00:53:44 I've been looking at Buso Audio and Zaor studio furniture. What other vendors would the panel recommend for studio desks with pull-out keyboard shelves?
00:55:40 Is there anyone going to give us a little taste of live from the EAA expo?
00:56:26 Zoom Room Pro AV - what are pin groups and how do you use them?
00:56:58 Is a dynamic mic, shielded xlr into system requiring mic or line level? can either levels be balanced? Educate please.

snippet.title: Graphics Tuesday Q&A - July 9th
snippet.description:
Join us as we add a character to a basic Unreal scene and animate their face in minutes! Nick Jushchyshyn will walk you through the process.

Submit your questions anytime https://www.askofficehours.global
Join our global community https://officehours.global

00:00 Intro
00:00:44 When using SoundDesk for internal audio routing within your Mac, do you use the SoundDesk Virtual Device to input audio to it or do you use Loopback? What would be the lowest latency?
00:02:39 There are several battery powered professional speakers ($800-$900 range) on the market, ie., JBL, Mackie, and many others. Do you have a preference for a quick sound reinforcement/PA setup?
00:07:05 Recent surveys have shown that the sector least affected by AI is the one that office hours are represents the audio and video profession. What do you attribute this to?
00:11:36 How much work and how many projectors are needed for hemispheric video - [link]
00:14:12 What happened to the audio stream for this momentousness Monday show? Did I miss the link? I really wanted to listen in to the show during work tonight.
00:16:04 As the AI industry strives for profitability, fears of an AI bubble intensify. If speculative investments fail to generate substantial revenue, many investors could face significant losses, similar to past tech bubbles. Agree?
00:22:41 With the Paramount/Skydance deal, the lines between tech and media blur further. Looking forward, what areas of both traditional media and emerging tech/AI will be most viable going forward?
00:34:46 Is Skydance buying Paramount a good thing for the industry (is more consolidation better)? [link]
00:39:45 After months of working smoothly, Continuity camera has broken for me. The mac see it as an option but I don't get an image and the iPhone shows the connection only for a few seconds - tried over wifi and cable -ios 17.5.1. thoughts?
00:42:07 Do you have any tips or tricks to encourage participants in a live learning event to turn their cameras on. Currently we are giving advanced notice thats its a cameras on event, providing branded virtual backdrops, managers with cameras and call outs
00:49:26 After 8+ years of iOS engineering I’m excited to explore 3D renders and assets. Would you recommend blender or some other tool to get started? Looking to render my vehicle and eventually 3D print it and assemble it. Thanks!
00:52:14 I'm helping with projection mapping for a play in a school theater. They've decided to use 3 or 4 Macs with a separate instance of QLab per machine. What is the standard way to control 3/4 network-connected instances of QLab as a solo op? Companion?
00:53:45 Cloudera talks about using LLMs to conversationally query business data. Do you think it will catch on broadly? ([link])
00:57:53 Would like to know Alex’s setup for a one click system to turn on/off everything in studio: outlets used, fx30 in sleep mode(?), “watch out for”, etc.

snippet.title: Choosing a Mixer
snippet.description:
Behringer, Allen and Heath, Yamaha, DigiCo... there are so many options! We'll discuss what console mixers are best for what event.

Submit your questions anytime https://www.askofficehours.global
Join our global community https://officehours.global

00:00 Intro
00:07:44 How do you determine the quality of a mic pre-amp? Can it be determined from just the specs? Do you trust most manufacturers to be truthful?
00:13:50 What small fader mixer (minimum 8 channels) would you suggest that would facilitate mix-minus via usb? or would you suggest embracing a digital mixer with a iPad?
00:24:13 Is there an 8 channel, digital mixer WITH faders? I can't find one and I'm sure I'm not the only one who would buy one!
00:31:17 Looking for a 6+ input mixer with clean pre-amps AND a usb interface. Built in recording and a trrs input is a plus. What do you recommend for small band performances and multi-person interviews?
00:40:53 I remember reading about a Game Creek Video truck that used LAWO infrastructure but a Calrec mixer. Would that be because the LAWO mc2 isn't as dominant in the US as it is in Europe?
00:43:37 Have you ever had an X32 mixer fail? Do you keep a spare to swap in? How do you manage your mixer config backups for recovering?
00:50:05 Just like pre-amps, what do we look for in analog to digital circuits? Might this also be external for high end workflows? Finally what specs do we need for digital signals and recordings?
00:55:32 Real quick! Best mixer under $1000?
00:57:21 Optical-Con, MADI bnc, Dante, AES50 - all multi channel digital audio. Discuss the differences
00:58:36 Recent Rick Beato interview with top-tier FOH mixer Dave Natale, who insists on analog mixers. What are the use cases in production for analog mixers? [link]

snippet.title: Unreal Engine - Getting Started
snippet.description:
Join us as we add a character to a basic Unreal scene and animate their face in minutes! Nick Jushchyshyn will walk you through the process.

Submit your questions anytime https://www.askofficehours.global
Join our global community https://officehours.global

00:00 Intro
00:08:58 Nick what GPU are you using for Unreal Engine, and do you prefer the Professional "Quadro" cards vs the mainstream "GeForce" cards
00:14:13 What is an Unreal Engine technician typically called on a crew? Where does their rate fall compared to, for example, a graphics op, a cam op, an EIC, and/or a TD?
00:16:23 Is the unreal launcher inside the same program as the Epic game store? Or is it separate from the games
00:19:09 Between the RTX and Quadro brands merging and various other branding changes, Nvidia's GPU nomenclature has become quite confusing. Which Nvidia GPUs are best for UE if Genlock is a requirement?
00:21:32 *** Panel Discussion - Unreal Engine ***
00:29:34 Have you found advantages/disadvantages between various brands of PCIe cards? Blackmagic, AJA, others?
00:30:58 What trends have you seen in the quality of assets available in the UE marketplace? Is AI junk creeping in?
00:39:12 How well does UE work on macOS versus Unity?
00:40:50 What are the restrictions of using the purchased or free assets for commercial uses?
00:44:59 Whats the largest project have you seen done with Unreal ?
00:53:02 How does that webcam tracking compare to a 30.000 dollar Faceware system or a even more expensive ILM TechnoProps system?
00:57:51 Can you use the timeline to create static scenes with Marketplace assets to use as a backdrop for a live event? How would you cue said scenes? (Is there a "QLab" for UE?)
00:59:23 How many different solutions have you had streaming data to Unreal Engine simultaneously at one time?

snippet.title: AI Monday Q&A - July 8th - How to read an RGB parade properly
snippet.description:
Submit your questions anytime https://www.askofficehours.global
Join our global community https://officehours.global

00:00 Intro
00:00:58 After the recent update to the ATEM mini line I cannot get the usb-c to output a signal to a monitor. Still records to disk and computer can see it as a webcam, but no monitor output. Tested multiple cables.
00:03:02 Long time listener, First time caller. Thanks for all you do! I have a client looking to do some interactive games during a digital learning event. On Zoom, in a meeting. Up to 1000 participants. Text based preferrably. Any suggestions? Thanks!
00:10:12 I'm messing around with an Atomos recorder and scopes. How do you read an RGB parade properly? It looks like the red and blue values are slightly higher than green above the "100" line.
00:13:16 I'm using ClickUp as a project and content management system. It's built-in AI assistant can use uploaded documents, Wiki's and content transcripts as a knowledge database. How is the panel using AI in project management and content creation?
00:15:32 Looking to rent a stand for use from the back of the room that will elevate a projector above the average person's height. Seen pictures of a truss like piece, but unsure what I'm asking for. Any ideas or help?
00:19:33 Has anyone tried the new TIkTok Notes app and have an opinion about it?
00:21:14 This morning, I installed the latest update for VPS Avenger (a soft synth) and had a lot of fun building sounds with it. Have you ever rediscovered a piece of hardware or software that you previously bought? ([link])
00:23:01 If I were to buy an Apple Vision Pro today, what would I need to know?
00:31:10 I played with LTX Studio (beta). How can the Entertainment industry survive these technologies? [link]
00:44:10 As a neophyte, I tried and failed to use a Zoom H6 Handy Recorder with Logic Pro for recording a single-room, multi-mic panel discussion. The key problem was mics picking up more than one speaker's voice. I'd appreciate any advice. Thanks!
00:50:58 I’ve been using Claude extensively not only as an information resource, but also to aid in adjusting to independence as someone with a disability. Could a well-designed genAI platform support adults with disabilities in gaining essential life skills?
00:51:32 Overlay vpn’s like Tailscale, Netbird, Netmaker, Zerotier which is your favorite for routing srt ndi and dante?
00:52:03 I've been using Slate VSX (headphones/room modeling software) and it has been wonderful for working in an apartment. Would there be a similar tool for mixing surround in headphones? ([link])
00:54:39 Post sound mixers for TV and film doing multi-channel surround (all flavours), do you think they're testing their mix on the Vision Pro with spatial audio?
00:55:25 Rode streamer x has been a boon for my mobile kit how has your mobile kit evolved lately?
00:57:19 On this day in 2008, thedissolve.com shut down with still no heir apparent in sight. Where are you getting your well-considered, meticulously curated film related opinion-editorial content?
